copy.value: You can register to vote online in 31 states. Many states also make forms available online that can be filled out and mailed in. If you don't have internet access (are you reading this as a print out?) forms can be obtained at state or local election offices, The Department of Motor Vehicles, Public assistance agencies, and state-funded programs that serve people with disabilities. Many times they are also available at public libraries, schools, and the municipal clerk’s office.
Americans living abroad can register by printing a form, completing it, and mailing it to their local election office. More information is available from the Federal Voting Assistance Program.

today.prob: You've moved or changed your name

copy.value: Even moving just across the street could cause you to be put into a different voting precinct. If you vote in the wrong precinct your ballot could be challenged and your vote might not count. Many states allow for a 60-day grace period to vote using your old address. Others may let you update your address on election day. In any case, it’s simpler to update your registration information in advance of election day.

today.prob: You've been struck from the rolls
today.fix: Verify your registration and reregister if necessary

copy.value: Even if you've voted in the past it is possible you've been removed from the voting rolls. There are a number of ways this can happen, such as a change of address or a technical glitch in the registration database. Some states also routinely purge voters that don’t show up. Before every election you should confirm your registration information so that you won’t have any issues on election day.

today.prob: You don't expect to be able to make it to the polls on election day.

copy.value: There are many reason that could keep you from a voting booth on election day. Voters who have a legitimate reason may be eligible to request an absentee ballot. Some states allow you to do this online.

Voters who live abroad can request an absentee ballot by mailing a form to their local election office. Note that state’s are not required to automatically send ballots to citizens who voted abroad in previous elections. To ensure you get a ballot, make sure you send in a new form at least once per year.

before_elec_day.prob: You’ve been struck from the voter rolls (again)
before_elec_day.fix: Verify your registration and reregister if necessary (again!)

copy.value: Even if you’ve checked your registration in advance, it’s still possible you could still be struck from the rolls before election day. Do yourself a favor and check again before your state’s registration deadline expires.

before_elec_day.prob: You're not sure what day or time the election is
before_elec_day.fix: Verify the election day and poll hours with your local election authority

copy.value: In the past some people have attempted to suppress the vote by spreading misinformation about when and where voting will take place. You should only trust government sources for information about where and when you will vote. If you suspect someone is spreading misinformation you should report it to election officials or local police.

before_elec_day.prob: You don’t know how to vote

copy.value: All states make sample ballots available prior to the election. Often they are online. If not, you can get one from a state or local election office.

before_elec_day.prob: You live abroad and haven't received an absentee ballot
before_elec_day.fix: Vote with an emergency write-in ballot

copy.value: Americans living abroad who do not receive their absentee ballot in time to vote may instead cast an emergency write-in ballot. Contact the nearest consulate or embassy for help.

before_elec_day.prob: You don't have the required form of identification

copy.value: In the past few years many states have passed controversial new laws that increase the identification requirements for voters. Many now require a government-issued photo ID. Make sure you know what is required in your state. If you don’t have the correct form of identification, make sure you give yourself enough time to get it before election day. Remember that you don’t have to drive in order to get a state ID.

election_day.prob: You're don’t know where your polling place is
election_day.fix: Verify your polling place with county officials

copy.value: Many websites, including Google, will offer instructions on how to find your polling place. Unfortunately, these services are not always accurate. The only official sources for polling place information are state and county governments. Many allow you to look this information up online, but you can also call.

election_day.prob: Someone told you that you could get arrested at the polls

copy.value: Various forms of intimidation have been documented occurring before voters go to the polls as well as at polling places themselves. Voting is an important and legally protected activity. Anyone interfering with someone else’s ability to vote is committing a federal crime. (TK: true?) If someone is warning away from the polls, you should report them to election officials or your local police department.

election_day.prob: You can't get to the polls

copy.value: There are both partisan and nonpartisan organizations that will pick you up and drive you to the polls—for free. Call your local party offices or county election officials to find out what services are available for your polling place.

election_day.prob: You're not listed on the voter rolls

copy.value: If a computer glitch or any other problem prevents your name from showing up on the voter rolls on election day, you are still eligible to cast a “provisional ballot.” You may be required to follow-up with documentation confirming your eligibility to vote. Poll workers should provide you with a receipt which will allow you to verify your vote is included in the final count.

election_day.prob: Your polling place uses electronic touchscreen voting machines
election_day.fix: Ask to fill out a paper ballot

copy.value: Many states continue to use touchscreen voting machines that are outdated and vulnerable to being hacked. However, polling places will often have paper ballots on hand as well. If you are told to use a touchscreen machine, ask if you can fill out a paper ballot instead.

election_day.prob: You're required to use a voting machine
election_day.fix: Check the machine for tampering or defects

copy.value: If your polling place has only touchscreen voting machines, there are still steps you can take to ensure the integrity of your vote. The first thing you can do is check for visual evidence the voting machine may have been tampered with. There are often tamper-proof security seals on sensitive parts of the machine. If these are broken, you should report it to a polling place worker and not use that machine.

A poorly calibrated touchscreen may register your vote for the wrong candidate when you tap. Check carefully that it marks the correct box before proceeding down the ballot. If the screen appears to be miscalibrated, you should report it to a polling place worker and use a different machine.
Most touchscreen voting machines will produce a paper record that documents your vote. If the machine you use does this, you should check the paper to verify the vote matches what you intended.

election_day.prob: You filled out your ballot incorrectly
election_day.fix: In most statesTK you can discard multiple ballots when you make a mistake

copy.value: Be sure to fill in your vote clearly and completely using the directions given to you TKTK

later.prob: The vote is not audited in your state

copy.value: Post-election audits are one way to verify that elections were conducted in a secure and reliable fashion. This usually involves manually recounting some percentage of the votes. Often election procedures are also reviewed for any problems. Unfortunately, 21 states either don’t perform post-election audits, or only perform them under certain circumstances. Encouraging elected leaders in your state to pass audit legislation is one step toward making sure your vote always counts.
